instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.P5VS3_EN_L: What is P5VS3_EN_L? P5VS3_EN_L is a signal that enables the PP5V_S3 power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.P3V3S4_EN: What is P3V3S4_EN? P3V3S4_EN is a signal that enables the PP3V3_S4 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD: What is SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD? SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
[PLAIN][SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops[/PLAIN]

Customer came in with this laptop which suppositiously have been peed on "a little" (Eww!!!!), the customer already cleaned the motherboard them selfs with pure alcohol in a hope to fix it them selfs but no luck.

The motherboard itself looks alright, it has some heavily green(?) corroded parts. But most parts are untouched or looking almost like new, the only few corroded parts are related to thunderbolt. I even tried to replace some of the really corroded parts but obviously that didn't fix anything.

When powering the system on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> drops from 13.3V quickly to ~3.4V and then slowly starts dropping until it hits 1.6-1.9V and goes back to 13.3V. At this moment trying to press the power button (or shorting the <SIGNAL>POWER_ON</SIGNAL> test point) will drop the voltage again to less then 3.4V. This is exactly the same result you'd get by disconnecting the charger.


All the S5 power lines are up, it does not have any S3 power lines and if I remember correctly only 1 of the two S4 power lines.

The system has no fan spin (and obviously no chime). The charger has a green light, but only when you connected it before <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> started dropping, if this happened you'd need to wait 10-30 seconds before you can connect it with a green light. Connecting the power on a cold start it will always give a green light

My guess is that the charger's protection circuit is working and disables the power output because something is shorting. I have no idea what though, I've tested some of the major power lines and there is no short to ground.

Any idea where to look?

These were the power lines by the way in a state where the voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't dropping:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 13.3v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 13.3v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 13.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.48v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.31v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 4.97v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.31v

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>: 2Ohm to ground
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>: 1.6Ohm to ground

Normal or dead CPU?

EDIT: Tested known working motherboard and it came back with the same values, alright. No short to ground, time to go back to the multimeter

Results off all the power lines I measured because why not, they're all in in diode mode

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>: >2000 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: >900 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 1010 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 463 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> >1000 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>: ~950 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>: 491 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 285 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL>: 253 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 729 (OK)
PPVTTDDRS3: 588 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>: 191 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>: 5 (OK?)
<SIGNAL>PPVP_FW</SIGNAL> >2000 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_FW_FWPHY</SIGNAL>: 598 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_PCJ_VCCADPLL</SIGNAL>: 250 (OK)
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>: 0 (OK, 2Ohm)
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>: 0 (OK, 1.6Ohm)
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL>: 145 (OK)

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
Issues in 6259 circuit. Check <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22/51/52 and traces. Does the system work when a charged battery is connected?
Best to use a fake Chinese charger for trouble shooting this one as it won't shut down.

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> missing... I hate working on devices that someone has touched before

I'll replace <RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> from a donor board, is it safe to just short the two pins of <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> with solder since the resistor is set for 0Ohms anyways? If not I'll just replace it as well

EDIT: Ah whatever, I'll just move <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> over as well, maybe that will make this motherboard be nice to me haha

EDIT2: Using a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> as donor board there is no <RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> on all of them, even though its in the schematic. (Pads are clean, no solder) Is this a case where they forgot to note it as NOSTUFF?

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
Alright just placing <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> on there seems to have made it less angry, PPBUS is 12.8V and it doesn't seem to be dropping / shorting the charger so definitely something changed. Its still not booting however.

I'll diagnose whats going wrong with those power lines tomorrow, thanks for your help so far

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
Hi Smiba I confirm <RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> should be marked "nostuff" at least on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> schematics.

I remember having a nightmare water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  where I had to replace all the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> region including resistors. Since I was following the schematic I soldered <RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR>...

It had the same issue you describe, it was droping  all the way from 12,6 to near 0 and back again to 12.6v

I did everything, replaced ISL 4 times, did again the soldering and checked back all traces, 18v transistors, sensing circuits, compared diode mode values... Hours and hours.

I left the board 8 months on the shelf and one day when comparing another same working <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, I discovered that <RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> was no stuff but not mentioned in the schematic.
I removed it and it worked!
The biggest ultimate maximum troll I had. 

So don't solder 1k <RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> and good luck?

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 0V, which is the reason why it never enters a S3 state, <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL> will stay high because of <TRANSISTOR>Q7911</TRANSISTOR> not being activated thus not setting it to ground.

How to proceed? For me it seems <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> should be generated by the CPU, is this an issue where the CPU is broken or should there be another signal going into the CPU to tell it to go to a S3 state?

EDIT: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is <0.5V, <SIGNAL>P3V3S4_EN</SIGNAL> is 0v. I think part of the issue is the system not even going into a full S4 state, lets see if I can find out whats causing this

EDIT2: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is low, so there is no attempt going into a S4 state

EDIT3: <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> is low, SMC-<SIGNAL>DELAYED_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is low. Bad SMC? It looks good around so probably not, I'll keep on digging to see what might be wrong

[QUOTE="jadao, post: 10496"]So don't solder 1k <RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> and good luck?[/QUOTE]


Glad I didn't haha, thanks for confirming!

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message: Look at the power management section of the PCH. It may help you figure out what signal has to go in before you get <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> out

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
[URL="http://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/public/us/en/documents/datasheets/7-series-chipset-pch-datasheet.pdf"]http://www.intel.com/content/dam/www...-datasheet.pdf[/URL]

Above is the datasheet. Look at the power management parts....
This forum add link thing is bullshit! Add a link and you can't edit post and it links the wrong fucking page.

Anyway, this may help.

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
Thanks, do you have any idea why <SIGNAL>SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is staying low which means <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> stays low too?

SMC related issue? Or issue with some signal going into the SMC?

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message: Sorry, I don't have an answer for you. I just linked you to the datasheet because I asked the same question once.

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message: Check voltages on <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>/1/2/3. Is PPBUS stable at 12.6V? It should now also be able to charge a battery.

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
All the <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> (Pin 1) on <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R1803</RESISTOR> are 3.34V, their outputs ranging from 2.97V to 3.32V

I just tested and the system does change batteries with no issues at all, the light turns orange and the battery reports a higher %

PPBUS stays at a steady precise 12.60V

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message: Check if 5V on L7260 is pulsing. Check voltages on Y2605. Was there corrosion around the clock chip?

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
Constant 0V on L7260 (Which is to be expected since its powered by an S3 rail), Clock signal exists on Y2605, although there is a 0.25V peak on its pins every ~2 seconds. I don't think this is supposed to happen as its at least 50 times more powerful in voltage then the clock signal is on my oscilloscope

There was some corrosion around the clock chip, I cleaned most of it off with some 2-Propanol and it looks very acceptable right now. However I'm slightly worried about possible corrosion underneath <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> itself.

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message: If the voltage on Y2605 is pulsing the machine is power cycling. If there was any corrosion at the clock chip replace it.

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
Replaced Y2605, still power cycling

Checked and replacement clock is working and looks stable for as far as I can see on my digital oscilloscope

Any idea what else might be causing it?

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message: Uhm, you replace the chip not the Xtal.

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
Oh, uh. Whoops... Sorry

I replaced the Clock chip (Yes, chip this time haha) and it worked! There is a fan spin, thank you so much!

Lets see if it has video

threads.title: [SOLVED][<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> trolling me, System not going further then S5 & voltage drops
threads.message:
Fully working, thanks a lot!

I'm really sorry for the mistakes I make sometimes, I'm still learning and hope I'll ever become as good as you.

Topic can be closed
